creator: surfer97301@yahoo.com
text:
I use the java api for ant quite frequently and usually I guess the java names
of the classes by looking at the documentation for the xml interface.  In the
case of unjar it took me a while to figure out that the proper class was expand.
 In order to do that I had to debug ant and jump into the code.  If the
unjar/untar/unear/unwar ant xml page mentioned that they are all just aliases to
the expand task then it would have made things a fair bit easier.  I think this
is even valuable for the xml interface.

Why would the typical Ant user care about class name that is backing the task
implementation?

Regardless, you can readily find these mappings in the defaults.properties file
in the org.apache.tools.ant.taskdefs package; marking as fixed-worksforme.
creator: carej@us.ibm.com
surfer97301@yahoo.com
text:
Typical ant user would care because instead of using different tasks which all
alias to the same one they could just use the expand task.  Actually makes your
xml a lot simpler and easier to search and modify all expand tasks when you find
you need to change the duplicate behavior to prevent duplicates.  A quick little
sentence about these tasks just aliasing to expand would be nice.

creator: carej@us.ibm.com
text:
Unless it was added post-1.6.2, there is no "expand" task. There is a task class
called oata.taskdefs.Expand that is the backing implementation class for unzip,
unjar, untar & unwar, but this "expand" task of which you speak does not exist.

Besides which, the manual already makes it pretty clear that unzip, unjar, untar
& unwar are all the same.
